page.title: 17THE THELWALL SMALL FERRY
page.content:
At the end of the 19th century the {MANCHESTER SHIP CANAL CO.}cut it's new canal through a farm at THELWALL.
The farmer had to have some means of transport across to his land on the other side. The company provided him with pontoons to move his cattle to and fro.
Later a small boat was used to carry people across at the same spot.{The {penny ferry was born. { Today in July 1985 the ferry still operates. It carries a dozen or so passengers at 10 - 15p per crossing.
The subsidy paid to the ferrryman by the MANCHESTER SHIP CANAL CO. now runs into several thousands of pounds per year.
